docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans stepped up attacks on Senate Democrats over economic stimulus legislation today, while Democrats argued that it was time for President Bush to get directly involved to avoid a partisan breakdown. Democrats said they would push their $67 billion bill, which emphasizes temporary unemployment and health insurance benefits and short-term tax breaks, through the Finance Committee on Thursday. But as Senator John B. Breaux, a moderate Democrat from Louisiana, observed, neither party has the votes to pass a bill.

headline.main: Amid Stimulus Wrangling, a Call for the President to Step In

docs.abstract: Congressional Republicans step up attacks on Senate Democrats over economic stimulus legislation; Democrats, who say they will push own bill through committee, call on Pres Bush to get directly involved to avoid partisan breakdown; Bush opposes provision of Democrat's bill that would provide added $20 billion for homeland defense (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: He has been introducing himself to the New Jersey public for six straight years, but James Edward McGreevey has never really gotten past hello. In his 1997 campaign for governor, Mr. McGreevey told the voters that Christie Whitman was an out-of-touch aristocrat who had failed to lower property taxes, auto insurance rates and the state's debt. He lost by only 1 percent.

headline.main: Man in the News; Flexibility in Victory; James Edward McGreevey

docs.lead_paragraph: Medica, a nonprofit health insurer, plans to eliminate about 20 percent of its work force, or more than 230 jobs, to reduce expenses. The insurer, based in Minnetonka, Minn., said the job cuts would save $30 million annually. Most of the reductions will be completed by the end of this month, a spokesman, Rob Longendyke, said. Medica sells health plans to consumers and offers Medicaid and Medicare services. Medica had $1.5 billion in sales last year.

headline.main: MEDICA TO ELIMINATE 20 PERCENT OF ITS WORK FORCE

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. JOSEPH J. ANGELINI JOSEPH J. ANGELINI JR. The Veteran and His Son He would not have wanted it any other way. Joseph J. Angelini Sr. and his son, Joseph Jr., were firefighters, and neither survived the twin towers' collapse. ''If he had lived and his son had died, I don't think he would have survived,'' said Alfred Benjamin, a firefighter at Rescue Company 1 in Manhattan who was partnered with Mr. Angelini for the last six months.

headline.main: Father-and-Son Firefighters, an Avid Dancer and a Love Sealed in Paris
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

docs.lead_paragraph: Let's say you're a primary care physician with a large number of H.I.V.-infected patients. Until a few years ago, almost all your patients died; now, with new medications, many are doing great, and you know you're making a difference. There's just one small problem: your practice is going bankrupt. What do you do? If you're Dr. Jeff Goodgame, you fret about your patients, meet with financial advisers and wrestle with your conscience. Then you close up shop and accept a job as a manager in the research department at a drug company.

headline.main: H.I.V. Practices Face Grim Financial Times

docs.abstract: Growing number of doctors treating HIV-infected people are struggling to keep their practices afloat; blame managed care, particularly health maintenance organizations, which pay primary care physicians the same flat monthly fee for every patient, healthy or sick; many HIV patients receive all their treatment from primary care physicians and make relatively great demands on their time, sometimes for as little as $5 a month; one remedy would be to create category of HIV specialists, who would be entitled to higher reimbursements (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Peres and Arafat Meet At European Gathering The Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, met for the second time in three days, joining European Union officials for an informal evening gathering in Brussels. While the men discussed Middle East issues, Mr. Peres is under instructions from the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, to refrain from substantive negotiations with Mr. Arafat for now. In the absence of high-level American engagement in the Middle East, the European Union is seeking to provide the Arab world with at least an impression of movement in the peace process. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: In June, a panel of medical experts issued a stunning indictment of the care offered to cancer patients in America at the end of life. Many of the 550,000 patients who die of cancer each year spend their last days in distress, suffering from pain, nausea, fatigue and depression. Their families suffer along with them, said the report, by the National Cancer Policy Board of the Institute of Medicine and National Research Council. The report, ''Improving Palliative Care for Cancer,'' can be found at www.iom.edu.

headline.main: Pioneer in the Battle to Avert Needless Pain and Suffering

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Kathleen M Foley, founder of pain service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, on inadequacy of palliative care provided to people with cancer and other terminal illnesses; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A plan newly passed by the Senate to broaden health insurance coverage for mental illness has touched off an intense lobbying campaign on Capitol Hill as advocates for the mentally ill try to eliminate restrictions on care. The goal of the legislation is what the advocates describe as parity in insurance: the elimination of widespread limits on treatment for various forms of mental illness.

headline.main: FURIOUS LOBBYING IS SET OFF BY BILL ON MENTAL HEALTH

docs.abstract: Plan newly passed by Senate to broaden health insurance coverage for mental illness touches off an intense lobbying campaign on Capitol Hill as advocates for mentally ill try to eliminate restrictions on care; employers, insurance companies and some health maintenance organizations are lobbying against proposal, saying it will drive up costs; supporters and opponents of 'mental health parity' say lobbying is intense because proposal currently stands greater chance of enactment than at any other time in past decade; measure would outlaw disparties in coverage between mental and physical illness under all group health plans sponsored by employer with more than 50 employees (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ismael Martinez has been jogging around the reservoir in Central Park for more than a year now, but for every mile he runs, he remains in the same place mentally, trapped between the beginning of his mother's nightmare and the end of his own dreams. ''Ismael's in denial,'' said his mother, Yvette Muyette. ''He cannot accept the fact that Mom is sick.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Mother and Son Struggle to Cope With the Burdens of Her Illness and Job Loss

docs.abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; plight of Yvette Muyette, who claims to have lost her job because of illness, discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With daily doses of bad economic news pointing to the first recession in more than a decade, government policy makers face increasing questions about whether they have the resolve and the proper tools to bring about a quick recovery. Just as the terrorist attacks required the United States to fight a new kind of war, economists said, the government faces an economic downturn that does not match previous scripts and that so far has not been particularly responsive to the combination of tax cuts and aggressive interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve Board.

headline.main: Staving Off a Recession When Only Old Scripts Are at Hand in a New Age

docs.abstract: Government policy makers face increasing questions about whether they have resolve and proper tools to bring about quick recovery, as bad economic news points to first recession in more than decade; economists say government is facing economic downturn that does not match previous scripts and that so far has not been very responsive to combination of tax cuts and aggressive interest rate cuts by Federal Reserve Board; Republicans want to cut taxes and Democrats want to increase spending to help poorest people; politically, tensions are running high; some Republicans are calling for resignation of Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, Pres Bush's point man in negotiating stimulus package; they are enraged by O'Neill's public suggestion that tax-cut bill House passed is 'show business' rather than serious policy proposal; photo (M)
